title: Sanjeev Gupta aims for carbon neutral steel in big restructure
text:
"Our integrated group will stretch around the world, with a financial and governance structure suitable for an intercontinental business of our size,'' Mr Gupta said.

The broader Liberty Steel Group will also include the Infrabuild operations in Australia, which comprise mini-mills in Sydney and Melbourne, and a national steel distribution business.

A spokesman said on Tuesday that Infrabuild would still report a separate set of accounts for bondholders.

Mr Gupta was last month forced to inject US$150m of his own money to help finalise a debt raising by Infrabuild after it scaled back a bond issue to US$325 million from an original target of US$475 million. The scaleback came after days of talks with potential investors who had baulked at the initial terms.

Mr Gupta's finances have come under increasing scrutiny from outsiders.

Lex Greensill, a former adviser to ex-UK prime minister David Cameron, has been at the centre of substantial funding deals for Mr Gupta's GFG Alliance.

Greensill Capital specialises in working capital finance and uses ''reverse factoring'' where financial institutions pay a company’s suppliers early. Rating agency Moody’s has been one of the critics of reverse factoring from time to time.

Mr Gupta's GFG Alliance bought the failed Arrium group, including the Whyalla steelworks and a nearby iron ore mine in the Middleback Ranges in northern South Australia for about $700 million in 2017. The Arrium businesses had been under the control of administrators KordaMentha for 16 months after collapsing in April, 2016.

The buyout of the Whyalla steelworks and the other Arrium assets saved about 3000 jobs in the township of Whyalla in northern South Australia. Whyalla has a population of about 22,000.

Mr Gupta, who is in Milan, Italy for a world steel conference, said Liberty Steel would be accelerating the "Greensteel'' strategy of using electric arc furnaces to recycle scrap steel instead of producing all material from scratch. The furnaces would also use renewable sources of energy.

He said Liberty Steel would be increasingly focusing on ways of harnessing new technology, such as hydrogen generated from renewable power sources, to manufacture steel.

Mr Gupta said Liberty Steel would be careful not to chase any one ''silver bullet'' in a gradual transition from existing blast furnaces towards electric arc furnaces.

Under the new Liberty Steel global structure, Mr Gupta said there would be three main divisions.

They will comprise Liberty Primary Steel, Liberty GreenSteel and Liberty Engineered Steel.

The Liberty Steel Group will have 200 production sites around the globe with a total capacity of 18 million tonnes.

Mr Gupta said Liberty Steel Group would be the eighth -largest steel producer in the world outside of China.

The SIMEC Energy arm operated by Mr Gupta will remain a separate entity and among the projects it is involved in is the $1.4 billion Cultana Solar farm in northern South Australia.

The Cultana solar farm comprises 780,000 solar panels and is located on land adjacent to the Whyalla steelworks.
description: The steel baron is putting his 200 plants into one consolidated entity with annual sales of $15 billion and a 2030 deadline for carbon neutrality.
